title: Electromagnetically Induced Transparency (EIT) in Warm Rubidium Vapor
description: Demonstrates quantum interference effect where a strong coupling laser makes an opaque atomic vapor transparent to a weak probe laser through coherent population trapping

parameters.description: Electronic signal processing unit for phase-sensitive detection of EIT signal from photodiode, improving signal-to-noise ratio
Electronic temperature controller maintaining vapor cell at 40-60°C for optimal atomic density control
RF source driving AOM at 80MHz to scan probe frequency across hyperfine resonance for EIT spectroscopy

physics_explanation: EIT occurs in a Lambda-type three-level system where two ground hyperfine states (|1⟩ and |2⟩) couple to an excited state (|3⟩) in Rb-87. The weak probe laser (795nm, |1⟩→|3⟩ transition) is normally absorbed, but a strong coupling laser (780nm, |2⟩→|3⟩ transition) creates quantum interference between excitation pathways, inducing coherent population trapping in a dark state |D⟩ = (Ω_c|1⟩ - Ω_p|2⟩)/√(Ω_c² + Ω_p²). When the two-photon resonance condition is satisfied (probe detuning plus coupling detuning equals ground state hyperfine splitting), destructive interference eliminates absorption, creating a narrow transparency window with steep dispersion that enables slow light propagation.

component_justifications.Probe Laser: Weak 795nm laser tuned to Rb-87 D1 line (5S1/2 F=2 → 5P1/2) - scanned across resonance to observe EIT transparency window
component_justifications.Probe AOM: Acousto-optic modulator allows scanning probe laser frequency across atomic resonance to map out EIT lineshape and locate two-photon resonance
component_justifications.Probe HWP: Half-wave plate rotates probe polarization to optimize coupling to specific atomic transitions and ensure proper alignment with coupling beam polarization
component_justifications.Probe Polarizer: Ensures clean linear polarization of probe beam for well-defined atomic transition selection and coherent interaction
component_justifications.Probe Collimator: Expands and collimates probe beam to match coupling beam diameter ensuring uniform interaction region through vapor cell
component_justifications.Coupling Laser: Strong 780nm laser on D2 line (5S1/2 F=1 → 5P3/2) creates dressed states and induces transparency for probe beam through quantum interference
component_justifications.Coupling HWP: Controls coupling beam polarization for proper atomic transition selection rules in co-propagating geometry with probe
component_justifications.Coupling Polarizer: Purifies coupling beam polarization to maintain coherent interaction with atoms and prevent decoherence
component_justifications.Coupling Collimator: Collimates coupling beam for extended interaction length through vapor cell and ensures spatial overlap with probe
component_justifications.Beam Combiner: Dichroic mirror combines probe (795nm transmitted) and coupling (780nm reflected) beams collinearly - critical for EIT as beams must spatially overlap
component_justifications.Alignment Iris: Ensures precise spatial overlap of probe and coupling beams through vapor cell for maximum EIT effect
component_justifications.Rb-87 Vapor Cell: Contains warm rubidium-87 atoms providing Lambda-type three-level system with ground state hyperfine splitting of 6.8 GHz matching two-photon resonance condition
component_justifications.Collection Lens: Focuses transmitted probe light onto detector for maximum signal collection efficiency
component_justifications.Probe Filter: Narrowband filter centered at 795nm blocks scattered coupling light while transmitting probe, preventing detector saturation from strong coupling beam
component_justifications.Probe Detector: Silicon photodiode measures probe beam transmission as function of detuning to observe narrow EIT transparency peak
component_justifications.Lock-in Amplifier: Electronic readout providing sensitive phase-locked detection of probe transmission signal, improving signal-to-noise ratio for observing narrow EIT features
component_justifications.Cell Heater: Electronic temperature controller regulates vapor cell at 40-60°C to control atomic vapor density - higher temperature increases atom number but also Doppler broadening
component_justifications.RF Generator: Electronic RF source driving AOM at 80MHz to scan probe frequency and can provide modulation for lock-in detection of EIT signal

expected_outcome: As probe frequency is scanned across the atomic resonance, transmission initially shows strong absorption (optical depth 2-4). When two-photon resonance condition is satisfied (probe-coupling detuning matches 6.8 GHz ground state hyperfine splitting), a narrow transparency window appears with transmission increasing to 60-90% of incident probe power. The EIT linewidth is typically 1-10 MHz (much narrower than natural linewidth of 6 MHz), determined by coupling laser Rabi frequency Ω_c and decoherence rates. The transparency window is accompanied by steep normal dispersion, reducing group velocity to ~1000 m/s or less. Varying coupling laser power shows EIT width scales as √(I_coupling), confirming Autler-Townes splitting interpretation and demonstrating quantum coherence and interference in atomic systems.
